description: Glossary for nutritionOS. This glossary explains the central technical and practical concepts of the system.

terms.definition: A modular nutrition system within MetaMemoryWorks. It organizes nutrition through logging, analysis, recipes, and pantry intelligence. All files are stored locally by the user.
The central logic file of nutritionOS. It contains rules for logging, analysis, recipe generation, estimations, and safety mechanisms.
A support file that helps the LLM interpret user input (e.g., recipe requests, analysis prompts, log entries). It does NOT determine behaviour by itself, but provides orientation.
The user's profile file, containing body data, goals, allergies, preferences, and daily routines. Used for TDEE estimation and personalized recommendations.
Append-only file containing daily nutrition entries. Each entry corresponds to meals or individual foods. Serves as the foundation for all analyses.

Structured file containing food items and nutrient profiles (e.g. food_db.json or category-based food logs). Used for nutrient calculations and pantry intelligence. Can be a single file or split into categories.
Interpretation logic that infers which foods are typically available based on the food logs. Enables realistic recipe suggestions tailored to the userâ€™s everyday pantry.
Collection of successfully tested or generated recipes. Each recipe contains ingredients, quantities, preparation steps, and optional nutrient values.
List of recurring meals such as shakes, bowls, or standard combinations to simplify logging and recipe generation.
Data is always added at the end of a file. Existing entries are never modified. This prevents data loss and ensures traceability.
A predefined structure from which a real log file is initialized. When a new file is created, the template is printed at the top.
If a food does not contain exact nutrient values, nutritionOS may use estimated values. These are clearly communicated to the user and based on typical food data.
Total Daily Energy Expenditure. An estimate of daily energy usage based on body data, activity, and daily routines.
Evaluation of nutrition data: macronutrients, plant diversity, fruit/vegetable portions, calorie balance, and pattern recognition.
